subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);

messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:

>Michael Feathers wrote:
>
>
>>Elliotte Harold wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>>>Why not install a SecurityManager that blocks calls to System.exit() by
>>>throwing a SecurityException, which you then catch? A littl ehackisjh
>>>but it should work.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>And it's a shame that we have to do hackish things to test code that
>>uses vendor supplied APIs, isn't it?
>>
>>
>>
>
>The problem here is not at all the java.lang.System API. It's the
>inappropriate use of System.exit() in the client code.
>
>

I agree, but I also think that it is appropriate to question why
recovering from bad choices is so hard. If the code was TDDed from the
beginning, the original developer likely would've localized his or her
calls to System.exit(int).

But, that aside, I do think that people ought to be able to write tests
for code that exits. And, I think that the should be able to do it
without having to think about writing security managers. They are a
higher level of voodoo than interfaces. And, as I replied to Cedric,
I'm not even sure you can get the error return code to write decent tests.

There's a lot of bad code out there. We have to do things to make
recovery easier.

Michael Feathers
www.objectmentor.com
